intro: Triodon anthospermoides, commonly known as the desert flax, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its low-growing, succulent stems and narrow, gray-green leaves adapted to conserve water. The plant produces small, clustered flowers that range in color from white to pale yellow, typically blooming in the spring. Its fibrous roots help stabilize sandy soils, making it an important species in desert ecosystems. Triodon anthospermoides is also valued for its historical use by indigenous peoples for fiber and food.
